thread.title: Lake Washington salmon returns are below expectations, but not a total wash out
thread.title_full: Lake Washington salmon returns are below expectations, but not a total wash out | The Seattle Times

author: Mark Yuasa
title: Lake Washington salmon returns are below expectations, but not a total wash out
text:
Here is the last update for Lake Washington coho, sockeye and chinook returns:
A general look back shows it was a very disappointing year for salmon species, which were all below historical averages.
The coho estimated return to the Ballard Locks fish ladder was 7,186 through Oct. 2.
Daily counts were 92 coho on Oct. 2; 46 on Oct. 1; 59 on Sept. 30; 59 on Sept. 29; 264 on Sept. 28; 360 on Sept. 27; 216 on Sept. 26; 75 on Sept. 25; 295 on Sept. 24; 353 on Sept. 23; 242 on Sept. 22; 419 on Sept. 21; 203 on Sept. 20; 223 on Sept. 19; 353 on Sept. 18; 119 on Sept. 17; 302 on Sept. 16; 177 on Sept. 15; 137 on Sept. 14; 118 on Sept. 13; and 421 on Sept. 12.
Most Read Stories Pair split; now can she divorce nickname? Next Air Force One will fly faster, farther with advanced technology What’s really wrong with the Seahawks? They’re just not as good Panthers 27, Seahawks 23: What the national media are saying about another Seattle collapse Seattle Seahawks to lift suspension on fullback Derrick Coleman Unlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. The largest single-day coho count at Locks occurred on Sept. 5 when 566 were tallied.
The chinook return was 5,477 through Sept. 27 and no fish returned since Sept. 25. The 10-year historical average is 11,442 through Oct. 2. In good years it is normal to see around 30,000-plus chinook return to the lake.

Daily counts were zero from Oct. 2 to Sept. 26; seven on Sept. 25; seven on Sept. 24; zero on Sept. 23; seven on Sept. 22; seven on Sept. 21; zero on Sept. 20; seven on Sept. 19; seven on Sept. 18; 11 on Sept. 17; zero on Sept. 16; 20 on Sept. 15; 66 on Sept. 14; 66 on Sept. 13; and 70 on Sept. 12.
The largest single-day chinook count at Locks occurred on Sept. 6 when 285 were tallied.
Bill Robinson, a member of the Seattle Public Utilities (SPU) Cedar River HCP Oversight Committee Member, said the prespawn mortality on the sockeye at Landsburg and the hatchery has been significantly lower than in previous yeas. Robinson says this is due to the use of antibiotics and peroxide treatments at the hatchery.
The chinook spawning below the weir is, at this point, five redds, which is very good for chinook in the Cedar and does not complicate the collection of sockeye at the weir.
“It has been good for chinook returning to the Cedar,” he said. “The SPU and (state Fish and Wildlife) staff have operated the tip gate at the weir almost all fall to pass the chinook without handling them which is a good thing. The sockeye which are passed along with the chinook, while not collected for the hatchery, do contribute to the naturally spawning population in the Cedar.”
The Landsburg fish ladder data on the Cedar River in Renton near the I-405 overpass showed 652 sockeye (278 female and 374 male). Single-day trap counts showed 46 on Oct. 15; 91 on Oct. 8; 137 on Oct. 1; 193 on Sept. 24; and 185 on Sept. 17.
At the Landsburg Hatchery a total of 2,227,000 sockeye eggs have been collected through Oct. 18. A total of 2,885 sockeye have hauled with 1,137 spawned (482 male and 655 female).
Chinook counts at the fish ladder totaled 254 fish (83 female and 171 male). Single-day trap counts showed 55 on Oct. 15; 44 on Oct. 8; 83 on Oct. 1; 52 on Sept. 24; and 20 on Sept. 17.
Coho counts at the fish ladder totaled 83 fish (38 female and 45 male). Single-day trap counts showed 49 on Oct. 15; 23 on Oct. 8; eight on Oct. 1; three on Sept. 24; and none on Sept. 17.
 
Mark Yuasa : 206-464-8780 or myuasa@seattletimes.com ; on Twitter: @markkyuasa . Mark Yuasa covers fishing and outdoors in the Pacific Northwest.
